function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"High levels of air pollutants such as formaldehyde, carbon monoxide, and particulate matter (PM 2.5) are associated with increased COVID-19 infections and fatalities.","Impact":"Increased risk of COVID-19 spread and higher mortality rates if air pollutants are not mitigated.","Mitigation":"Improve air quality through emission reduction measures and stricter pollution control policies.","Technologies":"Air pollution monitoring systems, emission control technologies, and air purification systems.","People":"Population residing in highly-polluted areas, especially in urban environments.","Owner":"Government authorities, environmental agencies, and local community organizations."},{"Description":"Negative correlation between aerosol data from satellites and COVID-19 fatalities, but positive correlation with infections.","Impact":"Misinterpretation of aerosol data may lead to underestimating the risk of COVID-19 spread.","Mitigation":"Educating and raising awareness on the difference between UV-absorbing particles and pollutant aerosols.","Technologies":"Advanced satellite imaging and remote sensing technologies for accurate aerosol monitoring.","People":"Researchers, public health officials, and policymakers involved in analyzing aerosol data.","Owner":"Research institutions, environmental agencies, and public health organizations."},{"Description":"Contrary to other pollutants, higher levels of O3 and SO2 from satellite and ground data were not associated with more COVID-19 deaths and mortality rates.","Impact":"Potential misunderstanding of the impact of O3 and SO2 on COVID-19 transmission and mortality.","Mitigation":"Conduct further research to understand the interaction between O3, SO2, and COVID-19 transmission.","Technologies":"Air quality monitoring stations, satellite data analysis tools, and atmospheric modeling software.","People":"Environmental scientists, epidemiologists, and public health researchers.","Owner":"Research institutions, environmental agencies, and public health organizations."}]}
